div.p: We usually think Inuit people don’t wear clothes to look good.
It is more important to be warm.
In the Canadian province of Nunavut, in the capital city of Iqaluit,
we can see that this is not true.
It’s high fashion in the high Arctic...
Beautiful jackets...
coats...
sweaters...
dresses...
coats...
"So this is the seals I work with...
beautiful."
From her home in Iqaluit, Aaju Peter designs clothes.
A lot of people like her clothes.
"So when I take this I can turn it into anything."
Anything from a coat to a skirt.
"This one was taken from a southern made vest that my sister had given to me."
"This is just so beautiful this is the signature of the North."
The Inuit still use seal skins but they also use modern materials like wool, cotton and synthetic materials.
However, they still use traditional designs.
One of the most important is the Amouti:
a jacket with a pouch for carrying a baby.
Women slip the baby over their head.
"There it is inside the pouch and you’re free like a bird, you can do whatever."
"I think since the Inuit are the ones who designed this outfit, Inuit should be the ones showing
the rest of the world how these Amouti's are made and how they are worn."
Because they are worried about the killing of baby seals, the U.S. and Europe banned the sale of seal fur.
"We weren’t doing that of course, and to this day we don’t do that, I mean we use every part of the seal."
"We eat the meat, we use the seal fat, but we need to use the skin to make money
and it’s not affecting the population, the seals are reproducing fine."
But the Inuit say that the seals are not in danger.
There are lots of them.
They want to lift the ban.
Inuit clothes have changed but they still use ideas from the past.
